DataElement.preferredDefinition: Descriptive term for a type of biospecimens gathered during a research trial.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: systematic investigation to establish facts._The act or process of gathering biospecimens for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes._The result of an action.

Concepts.definition: The act or process of gathering biospecimens for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes.

Property.preferredDefinition: A phenomenon that follows and is caused by some previous phenomenon.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: attributes of a patient's laboratory sample, including the source, condition, and fixative.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Systematic investigation into a subject in order to discover facts, establish or revise a theory, or develop a plan of action based on the facts discovered._The act or process of gathering biospecimens for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.::10: A measure of volume for a liquid.  A milliliter is approximately 950 times smaller than a quart and 30 times smaller than a fluid ounce.  A milliliter of liquid and a cubic centimeter (cc) of liquid are the same.: A hollow cylinder, especially one for holding or conveying liquids; anything shaped like such a hollow cylinder, e.g. an organic structure having the shape or function of a tube such as channel within a plant or animal body (e.g. fallopian tube).: The clear liquid part of the blood that remains after blood cells and clotting proteins have been removed.

Concepts.definition: A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.
A unit of volume equal to one millionth (10E-6) of a cubic meter, one thousandth of a liter, one cubic centimeter, or 0.061023 7 cubic inch. A cubic centimeter is the CGS unit of volume.

A hollow cylinder, especially one for holding or conveying liquids; anything shaped like such a hollow cylinder, e.g. an organic structure having the shape or function of a tube such as channel within a plant or animal body (e.g. fallopian tube).
The clear portion of the blood that remains after the removal of the blood cells and the clotting proteins.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.: Removal and pathologic examination of specimens in the form of small pieces of tissue from the living body.

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.
The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A liquid tissue; its major function is to transport oxygen throughout the body. It also supplies the tissues with nutrients, removes waste products, and contains various components of the immune system defending the body against infection. Several hormones also travel in the blood.

Concepts.definition: A liquid tissue; its major function is to transport oxygen throughout the body. It also supplies the tissues with nutrients, removes waste products, and contains various components of the immune system defending the body against infection. Several hormones also travel in the blood.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Bone Marrow Biopsy And Aspirate Biospecimen

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Bone Marrow Biopsy And Aspirate Biospecimen
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The removal of a small sample of bone marrow (usually from the hip) through a needle for examination under a microscope to see whether cancer cells are present.: An article which expresses the relation of connection or addition. It is used to conjoin a word with a word, a clause with a clause, or a sentence with a sentence.: (AS-pi-rit) Fluid withdrawn from a lump, often a cyst, or a nipple.: Any material sample taken from a biological entity for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes, including a sample obtained from a living organism or taken from the biological object after halting of all its life functions. Biospecimen can contain one or more components including but not limited to cellular molecules, cells, tissues, organs, body fluids, embryos, and body excretory products.

Concepts.definition: A biopsy involving the removal of a core tissue containing bone spicules and hematopoietic elements embedded in the marrow stroma.  This procedure is done in the hip area mainly for the diagnosis and evaluation of neoplastic and non-neoplastic hematopoietic disorders (e.g. anemias, leukemias, lymphomas) and the evaluation of the spread of solid tumors (e.g. carcinomas, sarcomas) and lymphomas for therapeutic purposes.
An article which expresses the relation of connection or addition. It is used to conjoin a word with a word, a clause with a clause, or a sentence with a sentence.
Fluid withdrawn from a body cavity, organ, cyst, or tumor.

Any material sample taken from a biological entity for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes, including a sample obtained from a living organism or taken from the biological object after halting of all its life functions. Biospecimen can contain one or more components including but not limited to cellular molecules, cells, tissues, organs, body fluids, embryos, and body excretory products.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: attributes of a patient's laboratory sample, including the source, condition, and fixative.

Concepts.definition: Systematic investigation into a subject in order to discover facts, establish or revise a theory, or develop a plan of action based on the facts discovered.
The act or process of gathering biospecimens for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
